author: By Tim Heffernan
title: Rental Competition: Not Just a New York Thing
description: High renewal rates and high occupancy are among the factors increasing competition among renters.
content: It’s hard enough for renters in New York to find an apartment they can afford in a neighborhood they like. Then there’s the added challenge of beating out competitors for it. But a September report from RentCafe suggests that Chicagoans — and Philadelphians, Milwaukeeans and Omahans, among others — face even tougher conditions.The study gauged competitiveness on RentCafe’s Rental Competitiveness Index (RCI), based on five metrics: occupancy and lease renewal rates, average days vacant, prospective renters per vacant unit, and the share of newly constructed units. The data, taken from market-rate rental buildings with at least 50 units, paints a familiar picture in the most popular places: demand is strong, people who already have a lease are unlikely to give it up, and newly built properties are scarce.Chicago (fifth in the competitiveness ranking) and its suburbs (first) have surged to the front of the pack, “challenging Miami’s long-held dominance in the U.S. rental market,” according to the study. The Windy City is attracting new renters with a combination of traditional economic springboards, like major employers relocating there, and newer ones, like the transformation of once-sleepy commuter towns into hipsturbias. The demand is intensified by high occupancy rates — only one in 20 apartments is available — and slow construction of new apartments, which account for just one in 1,000 rental properties in the Chicago suburbs and one in 200 in the city itself. This has led, in places, to rent bidding wars.Different forces underlie RentCafe’s list of highly competitive smaller rental markets, where Madison, Wis., and Fayetteville, Ark., lead the way. Madison is attracting tech startups and their employees, while Fayetteville is experiencing surging enrollment at the University of Arkansas.But the problem is the same everywhere: insufficient rental stock to meet the increasing demand. Even in ninth-ranked Manhattan, 24 percent of available apartments wound up in bidding wars this June (though rents themselves remained more or less stable, thanks to a jump in new construction). Perhaps London will become the next hot borough: In a bid to stabilize out-of-control rents, Britain’s Labour government is planning to ban rental bidding wars in England entirely.

description: Our editors discuss the season’s standout trends, from animal-shaped bags to one-legged pants.
content: Kate Lanphear, women’s style director: Florals are a spring perennial and we saw chintzy versions across the board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Radin
title: With Little Luck on Dating Apps, Some Singles Shift to Pitch Decks
description: Using PowerPoint presentations, business cards and billboards, some daters are taking their own approach to finding love.
content: In the spring of 2014, Dan Perino, a New York actor, plastered “looking for a girlfriend” fliers all over the city. “Just tired of the singles scene and hoping to meet the right person,” it said, along with his picture and phone number.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘White Bird’ Review: After ‘Wonder,’ a Bully Moves On
description: A boy starts a new school and gets a history lesson from his grandmother, played by Helen Mirren.
content: The world of children’s literature is more complicated than many of us might be aware of. The 2012 novel “Wonder,” by R.J. Palacio, for instance, has spawned several sequels or spinoffs to date. “Wonder” itself, about Auggie, a young boy living with Treacher Collins syndrome, and the unfortunate concomitant bullying by his peers, was made into a pretty decent picture in 2017. “White Bird,” a possibly unexpected origin story, is adapted from a 2019 graphic novel of the same name about the family of one of Auggie’s antagonists in “Wonder.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Scoles
title: The Food of Space Travel Could Be Based on Rocks
description: Scientists are studying whether future astronauts on deep-space journeys could transform compounds in asteroids into food.
content: Astronauts embarking on long-haul journeys in deep space can’t pack all the calories they will need in the form of freeze-dried food. They also can’t grow everything they’ll need, as onboard garden technology isn’t mature enough to keep them flush with fresh produce. Given those nutritional constraints, a group of engineers thinks future space travelers should pivot their diets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Rogers and Tony Cenicola
title: A Bartender, a Firefighter and a Giuliani Walk Onto a Fairway
description: The Brooklyn Open golf tournament attracts players whose backgrounds are as varied as their swings.
content: The sun was just starting to rise over the marinas and box stores of South Brooklyn on Monday as Sam Maurer, a bartender at Lucky Jack’s on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, wriggled his foot into a golf shoe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Can I Use an Expired Covid Test?
description: The expiration date listed on the box might not be accurate. Here’s what to know.
content: As the government ships out another round of free Covid tests, some appear to have arrived already expired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Harlan
title: Love ‘Heartstopper’? You’ll Love These Books, Too.
description: Earnest love stories by Rainbow Rowell, TJ Klune and Talia Hibbert will tug at your heartstrings while grappling with real, often dark, issues.
content: Break out the heart eyes and rugby kits: The much-anticipated third season of the gushingly earnest teen romantic dramedy “Heartstopper” arrives on Netflix on Oct. 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘The Outrun’ Review: From Rock Bottom to Recovery
description: Saoirse Ronan gives another stunning performance in a story about an alcoholic in search of healing.
content: Saoirse Ronan has made it apparent that she is one of the greatest actresses of her generation. Nominated for four Oscars before she was out of her mid-20s, the Irish actress is the sort of performer whose presence in a movie is sufficient reason to see it. She chooses her projects carefully, often movies about complex women, and throws her whole self into them, with unforgettable results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon and Mattathias Schwartz
title: Why Legal Experts Are Worried About a Second Trump Presidency
description: In a survey of 50 members of the D.C. legal establishment, many warn that Trump could follow through on his threats to prosecute his political adversaries.
content: As a candidate for president once again, Donald Trump could not be clearer about his plans to use the Justice Department to seek revenge against his enemies. During his 2016 campaign, his rallies exploded with the chant “Lock Her Up.” Now Trump talks about ordering prosecutions against so many people that his threats have become commonplace. “WHEN I WIN, those people that CHEATED will be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the Law, which will include long term prison sentences,” Trump posted online in September about election administrators, among others. It’s just one example in a long list that extends to President Biden and his family, Vice President Kamala Harris, members of Congress, prosecutors, judges and former F.B.I., Department of Justice and national-security officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: You’re Due for a Colonoscopy, but What if You Don’t Want It?
description: Doctors can provide alternative forms of screening for colon and rectal cancer but sometimes have a good reason to stick with the colonoscope.
content: This year about 53,000 Americans are expected to die from colon or rectal cancer. Doctors say most people should start getting screened at age 45. Yet many who are eligible skip testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: U.K. to Hand Over Chagos Islands to Mauritius, Ending Colonial-Era Dispute
description: After years of legal wrangling and negotiations, Britain said it would surrender sovereignty of the archipelago in the Indian Ocean.
content: Britain said on Thursday that it would hand over the Chagos Islands, a necklace of tropical islands in the Indian Ocean, to Mauritius, ending lengthy, sometimes acrimonious negotiations that raised questions about Britain’s colonial legacy, as well as about geopolitical rivalries in a contested part of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan
title: Inside a Trump Ad Saying Harris Will Raise Taxes and He Will Cut Them
description: A blunt argument hitting voters in the wallet, and a deceptive truncation of a quotation from The Times, pack a wallop.
content: Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign has aired this 30-second ad on television stations in Arizona, Georgia, North Carolina, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin this week at a cost, so far, of more than $450,000, according to AdImpact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: A Storied Luxury Liner May Soon Find New Life on the Florida Seafloor
description: The S.S. United States, one of the fastest ships to ever cross the Atlantic Ocean, may be sunk off the coast and turned into a habitat to marine life as the world’s largest artificial reef.
content: More than seven decades ago, the S.S. United States — a ship bigger than the Titanic — made its maiden voyage across the Atlantic Ocean, breaking the trans-Atlantic speed record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Sweet Potato and Tofu, Fall’s Hot Couple
description: Eat them roasted on a sheet pan with chili powder and topped with quick-pickled red onion, or tossed with a tangy mix of chile crisp, tamari and honey.
content: My mother loves to say, “What’s old is new again.” My wide-leg jeans? My Danish teak furniture? She’s seen it all before. One could say the same of my eating habits. I’ll feverishly fixate on a dish, only for it to fall out of personal favor a month or two later. But, much like in fashion, I’ll cycle back to it years later, seeking the comfort and familiarity of my own bygone eras.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Federal Judge Clears Path for Part of Biden’s Student Loan Plan
description: The ruling by a judge in Georgia could be just a temporary reprieve for the plan, which still faces legal challenges in another state.
content: A federal judge on Wednesday allowed the Biden administration to resume a student debt relief program for more than 27 million borrowers, but the decision could be just a temporary reprieve as the case moves to a different court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: aphorism
description: This word has appeared in 20 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word aphorism has appeared in 20 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 17 in “Want to Go Viral? Tell Your Story in 22 Parts” by Madison Malone Kircher:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Promised to Release His Medical Records. He Still Won’t Do It.
description: If elected again, he would become the oldest president by the end of his term. Yet he is refusing to disclose even basic health information.
content: As a presidential candidate in 2015, Donald J. Trump declined to release his medical records, instead offering a four-paragraph letter from his personal doctor proclaiming that he would be “the healthiest person ever elected to the presidency.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Friday Briefing: Israel Expands Evacuation Orders in Lebanon
description: Plus, paying countries to protect trees.
content: The Israeli military issued evacuation warnings for 20 more towns and villages in southern Lebanon, signaling a potential expansion of its assault on Hezbollah. The areas covered in the evacuation order lie above the upper boundary of a buffer zone that the U.N. established after Israel and Hezbollah fought a monthlong war in 2006.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Glenn Thrush
title: Lahaina Inferno Emerged From Smoldering Remnants of Quelled Fire
description: Federal investigators have concluded that hidden embers remained from a morning fire in the Hawaii town of Lahaina. They reignited later into a fire that destroyed much of the town.
content: The inferno that consumed the Hawaii town of Lahaina last year emerged from the remnants of a brush fire that firefighters had believed they had contained and extinguished, federal investigators concluded in a report released Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: How 2 Offhand Remarks by Biden Caused Waves in the Markets and the Middle East
description: The president’s casual disclosures underscored the power of his words — and how quickly they travel.
content: With the Middle East on the brink of all-out war on Thursday, people around the world were wondering when Israel might retaliate against Iran and what the targets might be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Trump Saw 2020 Election Results as an Obstacle, Not an Outcome
description: A court filing offers insight into his thinking and makes it hard to see him accepting another loss.
content: Three days before the 2020 election, one of former President Donald Trump’s closest advisers told a private gathering of his supporters that, no matter what happened on Election Day, the president was going to say he had won.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Garth Brooks Is Accused of Rape and Assault in Lawsuit
description: A woman who worked as a hair and makeup stylist for the country superstar says he subjected her to repeated advances. Mr. Brooks said it is “behavior I am incapable of.”
content: Garth Brooks, one of country music’s biggest stars, has been accused of sexual assault by a woman who said he raped her in a Los Angeles hotel room and subjected her to repeated unwanted sexual advances over a period of about two years, according to a lawsuit filed in a California court on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Walz Spoke of Gun Violence Affecting His Son. Here’s an Account of the Shooting.
description: At Tuesday’s debate, Gov. Tim Walz said that his son, Gus Walz, witnessed a shooting at a community center. A volleyball coach said Gus helped other young players to safety.
content: Gov. Tim Walz has spoken before of a shooting last year at a recreation center in St. Paul, Minn., that he said had an impact on his teenage son, Gus. But in the vice-presidential debate with Senator JD Vance of Ohio on Tuesday night, Mr. Walz went further in saying that his son witnessed the shooting, which left one teenager seriously wounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Should Junk Food Come With Warning Labels?
description: A guest essay argues that it’s time to use warning labels to steer people away from food that is unhealthy. Do you agree?
content: How healthy are your eating choices?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and the Bronx
description: This week’s properties are in Greenwich Village, Gramercy Park and Kingsbridge.
content: A one-bedroom, one-bath, 1,129-square-foot apartment in a converted carriage house that has a large coat closet and a vented washer/dryer on the first level; a kitchen with marble countertops and breakfast bar, a den/home office, 10-foot ceilings, skylights and a decorative fireplace on the second level; plus mini-split air-conditioning, a solarium, a terrace and a roof deck, in a five-unit condominium that includes an 1885 townhouse, a virtual intercom and a super. Kalav Mistry, Elegran | Forbes Global Properties, 917-822-1348; elegran.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: ‘Where’s Wanda?’ Is a Charming German Dramedy
description: A small-town European murder mystery but more stylish than most — and less miserable.
content: The Apple TV+ series “Where’s Wanda?” (in German, with subtitles, or dubbed) is another “suburbanites find themselves by committing mild crimes” dramedy, where the comfortably domestic are suddenly in close contact with the Bad Guys and discovering a bit about themselves along the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 7, 2024
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: An ‘Elegant’ Idea Could Pay Billions to Protect Trees
description: Brazil is proposing a fund that would pay countries to protect tropical forests that are crucial to curbing climate change. It would generate returns, too.
content: What if financial markets treated trees like shareholders?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
title: Filing in Trump Election Case Fleshes Out Roles of a Sprawling Cast
description: Donald Trump is the only defendant in the special counsel’s case that charges him with a plot to remain in power after his 2020 loss. But a newly unsealed brief provides fresh details about many other figures.
content: When the special counsel, Jack Smith, charged former President Donald J. Trump last year with plotting to overturn the 2020 election, the federal indictment filed in Washington had only one defendant: Mr. Trump himself, who stood accused of working with a small team of conspirators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian and Stanley Reed
title: Oil Prices Jump After Biden Says ‘Discussing’ Israeli Strike on Iranian Facilities
description: The president was asked about a potential strike on the oil infrastructure of Iran, which accounts for about 2 percent of the world’s supply.
content: Oil prices jumped on Thursday, after President Biden, when asked if he would support an Israeli strike on Iran’s oil facilities, said: “We’re discussing that. I think that would be a little … anyway.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: The big books of fall are like tomatoes, or zucchini: You look forward to them all summer and when they finally arrive, in a rush, you have more than you can handle. This week we recommend new fiction from Sally Rooney, Richard Powers and the Nobel laureate Olga Tokarczuk, among others, along with Ina Garten’s memoir and two fresh takes on Impressionist art. Any or all of them would make perfect company while the zucchini bread bakes and the tomato sauce simmers on the stove. Happy reading. — Gregory Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Masamitsu Yoshioka, Last Pearl Harbor Bombardier, Dies at 106
description: He was 23 years old when he took part in the attack that triggered America’s declaration of war against Japan. He rarely spoke publicly about it.
content: Masamitsu Yoshioka, the last known survivor among some 770 crew members who manned the Japanese airborne armada that attacked Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, has died. He was 106.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Port Union Agrees to Suspend Strike
description: The International Longshoremen’s Association received a new wage offer and will halt its walkout at East and Gulf Coast ports, which began Tuesday.
content: The International Longshoremen’s Association agreed on Thursday to suspend a strike that closed down major ports on the East and Gulf Coasts. The move followed an improved wage offer from port employers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A. G. Sulzberger
title: A New Chapter for the Times App
description: Today we’re updating our app to make it easier than ever to find everything you want to read and engage with.
content: To our subscribers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Schwendener
title: Lee Bul, South Korea’s Provocateur, Ruffles the Met’s Staid Niches
description: The artist for the fifth Facade Commission created Cubist sculptures that look forward and backward. The question is what more the Met can do going forward.
content: “I have many mothers,” the South Korean artist Lee Bul said as she stood in the Louise Bourgeois painting exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum in 2022. The curator Lesley Ma, who was there with her, related this anecdote to a packed auditorium on a recent evening when Lee’s four sculptures, titled “Long Tail Halo,” opened to the public. They are the fifth edition of a commission for a contemporary artist to fill the niches on the Met’s facade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bob Davis
title: Trump Lost the Trade War to China. America Needs a New Strategy.
description: America’s goal shouldn’t be merely to block Chinese goods, but to outcompete them. That will require cooperation.
content: When former President Donald Trump began his trade war with China in 2018, imposing tariffs as high as 25 percent on about three-quarters of all Chinese imports, he had three goals: Slash the trade deficit, which is his measure of economic success, bring back jobs to the United States and pressure China to stop ripping off U.S. intellectual property.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Mike Isaac
title: OpenAI Adds $4 Billion Credit Line on Top of $6.6 Billion Investment Round
description: The San Francisco company is gathering the billions its executives believe they will need to continue building new A.I. technology.
content: OpenAI has set up a $4 billion credit line from an array of banks, adding to its financial firepower after securing a $6.6 billion round of new investments, the company said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Can Drugs Like Ozempic Treat the Most Common Eating Disorder?
description: Doctors are already using weight loss drugs to treat binge eating disorder. But some experts warn that it’s a Band-Aid, not a fix.
content: People taking drugs like Ozempic say their appetites evaporate. The constant “food noise” in their heads — wondering what they’ll eat next, and when — goes quiet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘The Rings of Power’ Season 2 Finale Recap: Highs and Lows
description: The second season ended in a whirlwind of fire and steel, darkness and light, capping an eight-episode run with many ups and downs.
content: If you were to describe “The Rings of Power” in the simplest terms, the show would sound like a parody of prequels. An epic TV drama about how the rings in “The Lord of the Rings” were forged? What’s next? A detailed, multi-season history of Batman’s utility belt?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Ben Sisario
title: Lawyers for a Sean Combs Accuser Ask to Withdraw From Her Case
description: A dispute between Adria English, who has accused Mr. Combs of sexual misconduct, and her lawyers is the latest twist in the civil litigation the music mogul is facing.
content: Lawyers for a woman who accused Sean Combs of plying her with drugs at his famous White Parties and commanding her to have sex with guests are seeking to withdraw from representing her, writing in court papers that she had displayed “undermining behavior and questionable antics.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: The Whiskey Industry Is Bracing for a Trade War if Trump Wins. It’s Not Alone.
description: Business owners and foreign governments are preparing for high tariffs and trade disruptions, depending on the outcome of the election.
content: When you’re in the whiskey business, you’re always making predictions about the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: After Helene, Even Restoring Internet Service Is Political
description: Former President Donald J. Trump praised Elon Musk for bringing service to hard-hit areas. The Biden administration noted that the government was already on the case.
content: In the days since Hurricane Helene left a swath of destruction across the Southeastern United States, former President Donald J. Trump has praised the tech billionaire Elon Musk for what he has described as Mr. Musk’s personal efforts and extragovernmental largess to bring internet service back to hard-hit rural areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: How the North Carolina Legislature Left Homes Vulnerable to Helene
description: Under pressure to control housing costs, Republican lawmakers rejected standards meant to protect against disasters, experts say.
content: The amount of rain that Tropical Storm Helene unleashed over North Carolina was so intense, no amount of preparation could have entirely prevented the destruction that ensued.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘It’s What’s Inside’ Review: I Gotta Be You
description: A limp body-swapping comedy doesn’t really know what makes its subgenre so funny.
content: There’s only one really good reason to make a body-swap movie. Yes, OK, thematically they’re meant to teach us to be more empathetic and think about living in someone else’s shoes, blah, blah, blah. But a body-swap movie has one true purpose, and that’s to make us laugh at someone acting like someone else. “Freaky Friday”: a mom and her daughter switch places, and it’s funny. “13 Going on 30”: a teen girl ends up in the body of a mean, gorgeous magazine editor, and it’s funny. “Big”: a boy is in a man’s body, and it makes us laugh. “Jumanji”: four teens end up in the bodies of a beefcake, his sidekick, a dork and a hot lady, and it’s hilarious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Freedman
title: Putin Keeps Threatening to Use Nuclear Weapons. Would He?
description: Last week the president of Russia appeared to lower the threshold for his country’s use of nuclear weapons. It wasn’t subtle, and it wasn’t meant to be.
content: Last week, President Vladimir Putin announced a plan to change Russia’s nuclear doctrine. He said Russia would be prepared to use a nuclear weapon in response to an attack with conventional weapons that creates a “critical threat to our sovereignty” and would treat “aggression against Russia by any nonnuclear state, but with the participation or support of a nuclear state,” as a “joint attack on the Russian Federation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Daaaaaalí!’ Review: Keeping It Surreal
description: The French absurdist director Quentin Dupieux did not make a biopic of Salvador Dalí — he adopted the Surrealist painter’s approach to deliver a particularly loopy tale.
content: Quentin Dupieux’s new film opens with a shot recreating the Salvador Dalí painting “Necrophilic Fountain Flowing From a Grand Piano.” This is as straightforward as the nonsensical “Daaaaaalí!” ever gets, which is the least we can expect from Dupieux, a master of absurdist humor, engaging with the Surrealist artist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’: 11 Defining Political Sketches
description: Since the 1970s, the late-night institution has offered up definitive impersonations of American presidents and other politicians. Here are its most memorable political sketches.
content: Much like game-show parodies, fake commercials and the Weekend Update segment, comedic sendups of presidential politics have become a staple of “Saturday Night Live.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Hidden in Midwestern Cornfields, Tiny Edens Bloom
description: Farmers in the heartland are restoring swaths of the prairie with government help. The aim is to reduce nutrient runoff from cropland, and help birds and bees.
content: The little tracts of wilderness grow on Maple Edge Farm in southwest Iowa, where the Bakehouse family cultivates 700 acres of corn, soybeans and alfalfa. Set against uniform rows of cropland, the scraps of land look like tiny Edens, colorful and frowzy. Purple bergamot and yellow coneflowers sway alongside big bluestem and other grasses, alive with birdsong and bees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and Jacob Judah
title: In a Cat-and-Mouse Game, Russian Oil Tankers Are Flying New Flags
description: A shadowy network of ships has registered in Gabon, highlighting how Vladimir V. Putin is building an economy beyond the reach of Western sanctions.
content: The Jaguar, a tanker the length of nearly five Olympic-size swimming pools, left a port near St. Petersburg, Russia, last year, bound for India and loaded with Russian oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Joel Fleishman, Influential Expert on Philanthropy, Dies at 90
description: Officially, he was an authority on nonprofit foundations. Unofficially, he was an unparalleled networker among the nation’s rich and powerful.
content: Joel Fleishman, whose prominence as an expert on philanthropy was only the most public side of a man whose wide network of friends in high places, immense fund-raising talents and deep knowledge of subjects like classical music and fine wine made him an unparalleled influencer among the nation’s wealthy and powerful, died on Monday in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: A Recipe for a Striving America
description: The question is not whether to do industrial policy, but how.
content: I travel a lot. Just over the last several weeks, for example, I’ve been in some rural and redder parts of America (in Idaho, Kansas, Nebraska, Ohio, Texas) and some bluer parts (in California, Illinois, New York). My overall impression is that the social, economic and psychological chasms between these two zones are wider than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: JD Vance Is Smoother — but No Better — Than Donald Trump
description: Do not use normal appraisals for an abnormal election.
content: I’m ashamed of myself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein and Wesley Parnell
title: Another Woman Dies During Childbirth at a Troubled Brooklyn Hospital
description: After the death of a 24-year-old woman, Woodhull Hospital could face questions, for the third time since 2020, about the safety of its labor and delivery floor.
content: The pregnant woman’s due date was approaching when she arrived at a troubled public hospital in Brooklyn last month, complaining of stomach pain and nausea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Helene Knocked Out a Key Facility for Monitoring the Global Climate
description: The National Centers for Environmental Information in Asheville, N.C., sweep together data from around the world to help track Earth’s warming.
content: Among the many pieces of critical infrastructure that Hurricane Helene knocked offline in Asheville, N.C., was a key federal office for monitoring the global climate. Work is underway to get the facility running again, but the outage is likely to delay some agencies’ monthly updates on global warming and other climate indicators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuel Marc Gerecht and Ray Takeyh
title: Why Israel Is Worried About Iran’s Nuclear Ambitions
description: Despite the supreme leader’s stated religious objections to nuclear weapons, Tehran has been steadily making progress on its nuclear weapons capabilities over the course of the past year.
content: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, learned the limits of his foreign policy strategy this week: Even well-armed and well-trained surrogate forces can prove unreliable if a determined modern army disables them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: She Was Diagnosed With Brain Cancer, Then Wrote a Rom-Com About It
description: Sophie Kinsella, the author of “Confessions of a Shopaholic,” packs love, laughter and a harrowing real-life health ordeal into a 133-page novella.
content: Sitting beneath a skylight on a brilliant Sunday morning, Sophie Kinsella called to mind a posh, slightly weary matriarch who might appear in one of her novels. Flowing leopard skirt, check. Devoted husband who looks like Harrison Ford, check. Townhouse near the Thames with chocolate bars on a silver platter in the living room, check and check plus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yuliya Panfil and Craig J. Richardson
title: How We Unintentionally Created the Affordable Housing Crisis
description: Well-meaning regulations and reforms intended to prevent another financial crisis has pushed millions of affordable homes out of the reach of everyday buyers and into the coffers of investors.
content: America is in the throes of a deep housing shortage. Building new homes is important but also expensive and slow. And in the meantime, millions of affordable homes already exist. The problem is that well-meaning banking reforms — created to protect Americans — are pushing these places out of buyers’ reach and into the coffers of investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Around Dallas, the Church Scandals Seem to Have No End
description: In this part of Texas, a pastor with a clean reputation is not to be taken for granted.
content: On a Sunday morning, the pastor of Fellowship Church in Grapevine, Texas, took the stage with his wife to reassure their congregation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: At the Debate, JD Vance Put a Lifetime of Spin to Use
description: Mr. Vance sanded down Donald Trump’s edges the way he often sharpens attacks for rally crowds — picking the facts that can deliver the most impact and discarding the rest.
content: The debilitating self-doubt that nagged JD Vance as he graduated from high school was replaced with a thrilling new confidence that he discovered in the Marines when he thrived in one particular role: performing for the TV cameras as a media relations officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump Says He Would Try Again to Revoke Haitian Immigrants’ Protections
description: He again disparaged Haitians in Springfield, Ohio, and said he would end their legal status in the country and send them back. His first attempt to do that failed.
content: Donald J. Trump said on Wednesday that, if elected again, he would revoke the legal status of tens of thousands of Haitian immigrants who have been the target of false accusations by the former president and his running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, over the past month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Senators Urge Justice Dept. to Hold Boeing Executives Accountable for Safety
description: In a letter, Senators Elizabeth Warren and Richard Blumenthal criticized the Justice Department after continued episodes with the company’s planes.
content: Two Democratic senators sent a letter to Attorney General Merrick Garland on Thursday, pressing the top Justice Department official to take a tougher approach to Boeing and criminally prosecute the aircraft company’s executives for not doing enough to ensure passenger safety.
